title: TestScheduler: Should support *lack* of subscriptions in expectSubscriptions`
author: benlesh

comments.body:
Can you pass an empty array?

```ts
expectSubscriptions(source.subscriptions).toBe([]);
```

@cartant ... yes, that's a valid workaround. I think this issue is confusing enough that we should make sure that `.toBe('   ')` and `.toBe('-------')` work the same way as `.toBe([])`.

Further, it's plausible that people will have tests that expect subscriptions like `['^---!', '----', '---^--!']` or the like.  I think what we need to do is just take the `{ subscribed: null, unsubscribed: null }` (or whatever that outputs), and filter them out of the resulting arrays. Then everything should "just work" as expected.

title: Mark aliases
body:
### Documentation Related To Component:

### Please check those that apply

- [ ] typo
- [X] documentation feature suggestion
- [ ] documentation needs clarification
- [ ] error(s) in example
- [ ] needs example

### Description Of The Issue

It would be nice if the alias operators could be marked like "(alias flatMap)" or so.
author: BioPhoton

comments.body: I agree with this.
I would also not expose the aliases as separate operators in the rxjs.dev/api docs.

Definetly it would be cool! I just fear it is not that easy.

So the problem is that we are refering to the same exported member see 
```typescript
export { mergeMap } from '../internal/operators/mergeMap';
export { mergeMap as flatMap } from '../internal/operators/mergeMap';
```
Therefore the documentation inside flatMap also refers to mergeMap all the time. 
Currently we have no mechanism inside the docs to detect such "duplicates", also 
we would need some way to distinguish between the "original" one and the "alias".
For now I can't think of a solution for these problems.

I hope I could somehow express my concerns so that they are understandable (not really sure :D )
Maybe the `@nodoc` tag helps...

Hi @BioPhoton ,
Is this still open, let me know if i can be of any help here.

Hi!
I guess @JWO719 knows best how to fix it. I have no clue.

Do you have any idea?
I still don't know a proper solution for this problem. If anyone has an idea how to mark aliases or highlight it in a better way, I'm open for any suggestions and happy to review a pr!
Ok let me check if i can find any solution.
this is an amazing idea! Like that. @martinsik Would you like to file a pr for it!

title: Get response url from response.xhr on ie11
body:
**RxJS version:**
5.5.6

Observable version: 
0.18.0

**Code to reproduce:**

```ts
export default response => Observable.if(
  () => response.xhr.responseURL.indexOf(URL_PART) !== -1,
  Observable.throw('redirect'),
  Observable.of(response.response),
);
```

**Expected behavior:**
return response or redirect (works fine in ff and chrome)

**Actual behavior:**
"Exception thrown and not caught" in file Observable.js, line 165 in IE11

There is any other way to get response URL on IE11? Or Someone see something wrong in my code? I tried babel-polyfill but still same error.
author: l-pawliczak

comments.body: The problem is IE11 and old Edge don't have responseURL property on XMLHttpRequest object. Lots of frameworks will use request url as a fallback, but this will fail when 30x redirects happens.  The only reliable solution maybe is the backend server set some custom header to indicate response url, so I don't think rxjs need to solve this
I agree. This isn't something we can fix on the RxJS side.

title: add index to delayWhen selector
body:
Most operators include the index of the current element in the selector function For example `lter(predicate: function(value: T, **index**: number)` and ` mergeMap(project: function(value: T, **?index**: number)`.

`delayWhen` however is missing the index:
```
public delayWhen(delayDurationSelector: function(value: T): Observable, subscriptionDelay: Observable): Observable
```
However, it would be especially useful if `delayDurationSelector` included the index. That would make it easy to create an incremental delay, for example when `delayWhen` is combined with `retryWhen`.
author: Dorus

comments.body: Was this resolved by #2473? Anything else left to do here?

> Was this resolved by #2473?

That seems to be the case, yes.

title: Proposal: No more KitchenSink
body:
We should probably just have one global export file for the masses.
1. Is it huge? Yes.
2. Should people use RxJS 5 that way? Hell no. Use a bundler and only import what you're using.
3. In past tests, I noticed the gzipped size of Rx.KitchenSink.min.js was about the same as Rx.min.js, because of how the compression affected it.

If people are using the global export version of RxJS, it can be assumed that they're probably hacking around, and/or not really serious about reducing the size of their downloaded application.

At this point it's a little confusing to say "this is in Rx, but this is in Kitchensink" to people. Also, given how modular this library is, it would be easy enough for anyone to make their own custom build of RxJS 5 to keep around.
### Basically the idea is just to put everything in Rx.ts

Thoughts?
author: benlesh

comments.body: I'm in favor of this in general too, but had assumption those packages are similar representation of `rx.all.js` to `rx.lite.js` in RxJS4. So in case of anyone who'd like to have minimal, core packages (`Rx` currently), it's recommended to make custom imported builds of their own?
Agreed.
Been in favor of this for a long time, let's do it.

> So in case of anyone who'd like to have minimal, core packages (Rx currently), it's recommended to make custom imported builds of their own?

Yes. If someone cares that much they should be using bundling and tree shaking anyhow.
I would love to see this go out in a beta 8.

title: Add simple imports for observable creation methods
body:
### Problem

Currently when you want to use a creation method in an ad-hoc way, you need to import the type of Observable, then use it's static `create` method or new it up directly.

This poses two problems:
1. You have to know the name of the observable: `rxjs/observable/FromObservable` for example
2. It makes using it ugly:

``` js
import { FromObservable } from 'rxjs/observable/FromObservable';
const from = FromObservable.create;

from([1,2,3]).subscribe(console.log.bind(console));
```
### Solution

Add _additional_ files next to the observable files that export the `create` methods under a more useful name:

eg:

src/observable/from.ts

``` TypeScript
import { FromObservable } from './FromObservable';

export const from = FromObservable.create;
```

src/observable/never.ts

``` TypeScript
import { NeverObservable } from './NeverObservable';

export const never = NeverObservable.create;
```

etc.

That means that using these in an ad hoc way would be as simple as:

``` js
import { from } from 'rxjs/observable/from'; //LOL: from from from

from([1, 2, 3]).subscribe(console.log.bind(console));
```
author: benlesh

comments.body: How do you suggest to import `throw`?
@staltz right now it's `import { _throw } from XXX` same for `_do`, `_finally` and `_catch`.

title: Remove ScalarObservable optimizations for map, filter, reduce, scan, etc?
body:
There is an issue #1140 that just popped up (I was waiting for it). 

I'm neither hot nor cold on these optimizations. So let's discuss them:
#### The Good:
1. The optimizations only effect observables created like `Observable.of(a)`, but not `Observable.of(1,2,3)`. They only effect ScalarObservables.
2. The optimizations doubled or tripled the speed of the operators for these Observables.
3. No one should be doing `Observable.of(a).map(toSomethingElse)` very often. It's code that only really shows up in demos and playground code normally, and/or it's an anti-pattern usually.
4. Generally it's a bad idea to mutate outer scoped variables inside of a map or filter handler.
#### The Bad:
1. Users trying to leverage map to create side effects might see funky behavior for ScalarObservables
2. The mapping or filtering functions are effectively no longer "lazy". If they're expensive or they create side effects, unexpected behavior can result.
author: benlesh

comments.body:
### AGAIN: I don't care if we keep them or remove them

The idea was that we'd implement them and try them out during beta.

I'm in favor of this in general, but this specific `effectively no longer "lazy". If they're expensive or they create side effects, unexpected behavior can result` is bit concern. Every user of `of(x)` need to be aware of behavior if we're going with this.
We should make them lazy. If someone wants to optimize so their ScalarObservable chains are only invoked once, they can multicast with a ReplaySubject.

This all sounds good... I'll let this simmer overnight.

I think we should also try to add some "protips" or something to the docs that say things like "If you're creating chains like `Observable.of(a).map(doSomething)`, you might be doing something weird."
I'm also rather neutral on this one, but I tend to agree with Paul.
Meh. Let's remove them for now. Individuals that want this behavior could always monkey-patch ScalarObservable I suppose.

Just before this is done in response to my issue can I double check that the problem I had is actually what's been discussed? I have a feeling it might just be a bug (see my latest comment on the issue)....

FWIW I do agree though, just not in my name! :smile:
There are two issues: 1. the optimization which were discussing removing here, and 2. an apparent bug in the optimization that needs to be fixed or removed with the optimization.

title: Tests asserting unsubscription chains don't break
body:
We need to add tests that each operator propagates unsubscription from the destination to the source.

Here is an example:

``` js
  it('should not break unsubscription chain when unsubscribed explicitly', function () {
    var e1 =     hot('--a--b--c--d--e----|');
    var unsub =      '         !          ';
    var e1subs =     '^        !          ';
    var skip =   hot('-------------x--|   ');
    var skipSubs =   '^        !          ';
    var expected =  ('----------          ');

    var result = e1
      .mergeMap(function (x) { return Observable.of(x); })
      .skipUntil(skip)
      .mergeMap(function (x) { return Observable.of(x); });

    expectObservable(result, unsub).toBe(expected);
    expectSubscriptions(e1.subscriptions).toBe(e1subs);
    expectSubscriptions(skip.subscriptions).toBe(skipSubs);
  });
```

Notice the use of the `mergeMap` sandwich there.

title: (re)consider dist strategery
body:
per the new changes in Typescript 1.6.2 and Angular2's support to change over to it, some structural issues i've run into while attempting to (properly) bring Rx into NG2 could be eased with some changes:

Having the `typings: "./dist/es6/cjs"` field in package.json is a good start (or will be, once a release ships) but this only allows usage of the root entry point, eg:
`import {Observable} from '@reactivex/rxjs'` (and there's a mismatch between cjs/es6 paths here)

If I want to grab Observable from a TypeScript codebase, and leverage the generated type information, I can't: 

`import Observable from '@reactivex/rxjs/dist/cjs/Observable'`
fails because TS cannot find module, since .d.ts file isn't in this location.

`var Observable = require('@reactivex/rxjs/dist/cjs/Observable');`
"works" but can't find the typedefs, so it can't be subclassed / typechecked etc.

`import Observable from '@reactivex/rxjs/src/Observable'` "works" internally (eg, in the NG2 build process / typechecking) but fails immediately in public because that transpiles to `require('@reactivex/rxjs/src/Observable') //implied .js`

Suggestions:
- while I know you're using Babel to generate CJS because of defaults, it would be helpful to have the generated .d.ts end up in the same path. That would alleviate most of our issues.
- Add an index.ts file that simply `exports * from './src/Rx'`
- Consider using TS to transpile the src folder (in place) before shipping?

Happy to do any/all of the above but wanted to discuss before PR'ing.

cc @alexeagle as he's been dealing with the typings stuff in NG2
author: robwormald

comments.body: As long as it doesn't hurt the behavior of the library, specifically the issue around default exports in CJS, I don't see a problem with it.
Honestly, I was sort of waiting for issues like this to arise. I'm way more likely to use Babel with RxJS than TypeScript, personally. So I haven't really dog-fooded any typings issues.

title: Perf regression in `zip` operator
body:
Micro perf tests are now showing `zip` to be 75% slower than Rx 4. I'm not sure what happened there.

There are a few possibilities:
1. Changes made to `zip` to support iterators caused the regression, but weren't noticed.
2. Rx 4.0.0 has improved `zip` since I've last run the tests against it, and it's quite a bit faster.
3. Both?

Either way, we need to get it back up to speed
author: benlesh

comments.body: @blesh pretty safe to say I did a lot of perf work for 4.x to beat 5.x to challenge us all

Seems v4 did quite good optimization,  

> old zip() with immediate scheduler x 96,348 ops/sec 3.19% (83 runs sampled)
> new zip() with immediate scheduler x 51,863 ops/sec 3.46% (84 runs sampled)
>         85.77% slower than Rx v 4.0.0
> 
> old zip() with immediate scheduler x 7,586 ops/sec 2.89% (86 runs sampled)
> new zip() with immediate scheduler x 56,612 ops/sec 2.74% (82 runs sampled)
>         646.22% faster than Rx v 3.1.2
Cool, @mattpodwysocki!  Well I guess it's not a "regression" then.
... but still, we need it to be faster.
It seems there are some bugs in the 4.0 zip implementation. Closing this until we're sure 4.0 zip is working properly.

title: Add throttle operator with durationSelector
body:
Relates to some discussion at #493..

The only thing we need to figure out, is whether to attempt an overload on the existing operator, or rename it to `throttleTime` and add a `throttle` operator that accepts an observable.

It depends on the complexity of the overload and the perf hit.
author: benlesh

comments.body:
This should end up mirroring what was done for `debounce` and `debounceTime`

Also the tests are weak around this operator.
I can do this.

title: A development "watch" process
body: I'm sure there are easy ways to do this with command line tools, but I haven't looked into it. Either way I think this would be great, especially if we get #494 done.

comments.body: I'll also look for this as well as #494.

title: Move linting to start of build_test and have it fail quickly
body: Just what it says. I think it would be ideal to know that linting failed immediately, so you don't have to wait for the build and the tests before you realize you have a typo.

comments.body: This'll be quite quick changes, I'll create PR.

title: Use Closure Compiler on global output file
body: In an effort to reduce library size, use Google Closure compiler on output global `Rx.js` file to create `Rx.min.js` ... currently, uglify isn't doing that great of a job reducing the size of the minified output.
author: benlesh

comments.body: Seems like this can be closed.

title: Remove repeated "runtime" code from global output.
body:
Currently the ES6 -> ES5 transpilation process is putting class assertion functions inline with each module file. We should get rid of that so those class related functions are only defined once.

cc/ @jeffbcross @vsavkin

comments.body: I assume this can be closed by we're moving away from babel, what do you think? @blesh
I agree.

title: Add micro perf tests for existing operators
body:
From #100 
- [x] buffer (buffer(obs))
- [ ] bufferTime (bufferWithTime)
- [ ] bufferToggle (buffer(obs, fn))
- [ ] bufferWhen (buffer(fn))
- [ ] delay
- [x] forkJoin
- [x] mapTo (map(obj))
- [ ] multicast
- [ ] publish
- [x] retry
- [ ] retryWhen
- [x] skipUntil
- [ ] subscribeOn
- [ ] switchMap
- [ ] takeUntil
- [x] toPromise
- [ ] window (window(obs))
- [ ] windowTime (windowWithTime)
- [ ] windowToggle (window(obs, fn))
- [ ] windowWhen (window(fn))
- [ ] withLatestFrom
- [ ] zipAll
author: benlesh

comments.body: @blesh maybe I'm naive here, but why is `mapTo` required when `map` for example in RxJS supports wrapping objects that are passed in.

> @blesh maybe I'm naive here, but why is mapTo required when map for example in RxJS supports wrapping objects that are passed in.

reducing type checking in a really, really commonly used operator as well as making it less polymorphic.
I think for the most part we have the metrics we need here. Anything missing can be added ad hoc. Closing this issue.
This thread has been automatically locked since there has not been any recent activity after it was closed. Please open a new issue for related bugs.

title: Notification `create` methods could return consts in some cases
body: In #206, @abersnaze pointed out that we could save on object allocations in `materialize` and `dematerialize` (as well as our TestScheduler) by returning the same references, or perhaps tokens of some sort (to further reduce object allocations), for common return values like `Notification.createComplete()` and `Notification.createNext(null)`, etc.
author: benlesh

comments.body:
Interested in creating PR for this - which way would be feasible? Initial thought I could think some ways like
- create `NotificationLite` class as similar to RxJava does have
- allow additional parameter into existing interface like `createComplete(getStaticReference?:boolean)` to return specific object reference
- let existing interface automatically returns by value, i.e `createNext(value) { if (!value) { return existingReference }....}`

Or possibly other, better way. Any suggestion would be appreciated.
I think our current implementation is already pretty "lite"... but we can probably just use a static reference for all `complete` notifications, as well as `undefined` value notifications.
Got it, will try to create to return static reference per specific cases as similar to 3rd way's pseudo does.

title: rename `switchAll` to `switch`
body: The `All` is implied, really. Since it was just `switch` in previous versions of Rx, I think we can leave it `switch`. (this is similar to not wanting `zipMap` and just having `zip`)
author: benlesh

title: Rename `flatMap` to `mergeMap`
body:
Again, the result of bike shedding elsewhere. cc/ @jhusain 

However with this one, since flatMap is so popular and known from other languages/libraries, we might want to leave an alias.
author: benlesh

comments.body: I think we **should** leave `flatMap()` as an alias if we do this change. flatMap is very popular terminology as to flattening mapping name so it's not better to remove `flatMap` name for interoperability of concept of this area.

No problem leaving this alias.

JH

> On Sep 17, 2015, at 7:34 PM, Tetsuharu OHZEKI notifications@github.com wrote:
> 
> I think we should leave flatMap() as an alias if we do this change. flatMap is very popular terminology as to flattening mapping name so it's not better to remove flatMap name for interoperability of concept of this area.
> 
> 
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub.

Yes. Thank you, @pselle!

title: Find all tests with `setTimeout` in them and replace them
body: Now that we have the TestScheduler, I'm sick of waiting for the tests with _actual_ timing in them. I need to find them and kill them, replacing them with TestScheduler "marble" tests.

comments.body: Candidates are (most of) all test cases exist under /spec/**, is that correct?
Yes, that's what I'm talking about.
I think we've accomplished this for the most part.

title: Change scheduler `schedule` signature
body:
Funny enough, I feel like this is the first way I did scheduling, but @trxcllnt is resurrecting it...

Instead of:

``` TypeScript
schedule(delay: number, state:any, work:(state?: any) => Subscription | void) : Subscription
```

it should be:

``` TypeScript
schedule(work:(state?: any) => Subscription | void, delay: number = 0, state?: any) : Subscription
```

This actually brings it _sort of_ inline with methods like `setTimeout` to a degree.
author: benlesh

comments.body: Any reason you have the state parameter?
This was done a while ago.
closed by 526e4c92f0a2b1670aebf7cde39063657f47b684
Closed by the above PR :smile:
Thanks again @pselle!

title: Add distinctUntilChanged operator
body: Might be nice to re-think the API on this one slightly. It seems very uncommon to use the keySelector first argument. Interested in hearing anecdotes to the contrary.
author: steveorsomethin

comments.body:
>  It seems very uncommon to use the keySelector first argument.

Agreed.

The comparer can be used to select the key, if needed. So this

``` js
var obs = observable.distinctUntilChanged(x => x.id, (x, y) => x === y);
```

becomes

``` js
var obs = observable.distinctUntilChanged((x, y) => x.id === y.id);
```
closed by f9ba4da3fe26db233c7553cf070bd769bb182515
closed by 47b178bddba65272f957602b8a6c69f79cc73da6

title: Scheduler design - Input needed
body:
I spent a little time talking with @trxcllnt yesterday about scheduler design. I've also glossed over this briefly with @jhusain and @benjchristensen 

I have a REALLY, REALLY primitive impl in the codebase now, but it needs work. In particular it needs a better design.

Right now it's a global scheduler. But you'll notice I added a dispose() method to it. This is because I initially created it as a class, and thought scheduling might be instance based. This would make scheduling more flexible. However, global scheduling is _very_ useful for things like Framework lifecycles (@igorminar, @machty).

I'm looking for input as to how to make this flexible but easy to understand for authors.
author: benlesh

comments.body: Also, PLEASE tell me if I'm doing something stupid. lol

... and I do realize the primitive scheduler I've put in place is an "execute until done" sort of scheduler. Meaning it doesn't provide gaps for other code execution. This is a bare-metal simplistic impl. I think for most browser-based use cases, adding gaps ala MicroTask scheduling probably isn't completely necessary because the event stream sources themselves will be async, but there's definitely a need for that type of scheduler.
@blesh sounds like you meant to provide a link to the code, no?
Closing this for now. I feel like the Scheduling is in an okay place.
